body:
I think it's no need to export that temporary variable. if you have a script called *test.sh*:
```
#!/bin/bash
echo ${my_var}
```
which does nothing but print the variable *my_var*, and you execute this script in this way:
```
my_var=100 ./test.sh
```
the output will be 100 and *my_var* will be known (and only be known) to this script. See the following quick test:
```
chweng@honghuTX:/dev/shm/tmp$ my_var=100 ./test.sh
100
chweng@honghuTX:/dev/shm/tmp$ env | grep my_var
chweng@honghuTX:/dev/shm/tmp$
```
